System pressure at relief valve opening pressure.  Saturation temperature.  

External fire is a credible scenario in the relief calc.  However, Case 13 uses governing chemical, which may not be representative of conservative dispersion model.  

Estimate here based on rate of flow across 6-in orifice (PSV orifice).  Remainder of piping is >= 10-inch, so losses should be minimal.

Relief is to blowdown tank.  Dispersion model assumes only vapor component is discharged to environment.

backflow causes high pressure

Failure of cooling water on first condenser from synthesis reactor results in high temperature process gas entering brine condenser.  The brine condenser is rated for 60 barg at 50 C and the gas stream is at 150 C.  Assumed failure of reactor.
LOPAID: 1 Exchanger failure due to high temperature

Description: During start up, the reactor is at 130 C and 52 barg.  The off spec material is sent through an exchanger W03 which has a pressure rating of 10 barg.  The material flows through a pipe rated for 16 barg. - the flow will be restricted by changing the hole size until the flow is 4,000 kg/hr which is the start up rate
Failure of the pressure control valve supressing vaporization results in overpressure of 40 barg piping with up to 52.5 psig material.
Closure of the EIV between the crystallizer vent and the methanol column causes pressurization of the crystallizer and failure of the vessel

The centrifuge and it's seal pot gravity drain to W4.  W4 normally operates at slightly positive pressure but in an overfill or high pressure scenario vapor or liquid could backflow and fill the pot and centrifuge.  The pot and centrifuge are only rated for 0.1 barg and could be overpressured by this flow.

The centrifuge and it's seal pot gravity drain to W4.  W4 normally operates at slightly positive pressure but in an overfill or high pressure scenario vapor or liquid could backflow and fill the pot and centrifuge.  The pot and centrifuge are only rated for 0.1 barg and could be overpressured by this flow. - COPY - 09/29/2023 08:42:55 -04:00

Loss of level in the reactor can result in depressurization of the reactor to K1.  The high pressure gas entering K1 would not condense and could pressurize K1 to the point of failure.  K1 is rated for 3 barg and the source gas is at least 52.5 barg.

Deep vacuum spikes have been recorded on the Y-line methanol column. This happened 4 times in 3 years.  The Y-line column is also operated under vacuum occasionally (between 0 to -1 psig).  The final reactor seal pot drain line is connected to the N-line methanol column drain line to AZ-02 and could cause vacuum to be pulled in in CN-D-42 which is not rated for full vacuum (-7.4 psig).  The vacuum vent on CN-D-42 could open and cause air to be introduced into the methanol column system. This could result in an internal deflagration in the methanol column, damage to the column, and a leak of methanol from the largest flange to the area.

overfill of Tank 58 or 59 leading to release of material from top dome of tank.  low pressure storage tank (MAWP 8 "H2O) with anchoring at base.  assumed failure mode to be at top weld seam based on the presence of anchoring.

If this column experience loss of cooling this could cause material in the column to heat up and eventually build pressure in the column, leading to the weak point of the system rupturing - in this case the reflux drum.  If this occurred, material would be released into the area potentially leading to a fire or inhalation hazard.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
The piece of equipment with the lowest MAWP in the system is the reflux drum 99C-D-333 (MAWP 24 psig).  

Assumptions:
- Maximum mass/relief rate based on feed rate to column for 1 hour: max rate over last year (2023) was ~1m3/min (liquid) --> 60 m3/hr = 53703 kg/hr = 118395 lb/hr
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (Mike James suggested 1 psig).  All acetic acid will vaporize.
- Storage temperature is the the utility temperature which is the max temperature the system could experience (worst case)
- Discharge diameter was based on largest piping going to the reflux drum (8 in)
- The separation is acetic acid from unspecified high boilers.  Pure acetic acid was assumed due for highest vapor pressure (worst case).
- Release elevation was listed as 31.6 m (height of column) until confirmed by operations.
- Process area population density assumed to be 3 until further discussion with operations representative
- Distance to non-process plant population was 40 m due to the river

Information still needed from operations:
- Release elevation (currently assumed to be column height - couldn't find elevation drawings)
- Occupancy (have discussion with operations using occupancy spreadsheet)
- Secondary target table needs to be done considering liquid in reflux drum during release
      - Set temp/press to 117C / 0 psig (acetic acid stays liquid but is near boiling)
      - Determine if there's a dike the reflux drum material would fall into
      - Worst case is reflux drum being full, so use full volume as a liquid (convert to mass)

Nitrogen from loading left open to D-203 (typically used to pressure up D-203, PV 2102 is blocked in). Sphere can overpressure with loss of containment if PSV-2161A/B or PSV-2162 A/B relieves; toxic, fire/explosion hazards.
Loss of cooling to E-201. Vaporization of MEA70 with potential for over pressurization of TK-207 (9 psig design) with loss of containment if MAWP is exceeded.
Loss of Cooling to E-120. Higher temperature MEA to D-120 A/B. Potential to overpressure D-120 A/B with loss of containment if MAWP is exceeded; toxic and fire/explosion hazards.

FC-1451 loop fails and FV-1451 opens. Sustained flow to D-120A or D-120B (design pressure is 50 psig) could hydraulically fill, pressurize from P-108/ 106B head and operating pressure from D-107 (140 psig) with loss of containment if pressure exceeds MAWP of the tank; toxic and fire hazards.

If too much methyl acetate is added to the railcar due to human error, equipment malfunction, or other cause, a methyl acetate spill could occur and, if ignited, lead to possible fire. Building target here shows Critical, which is appropriate.

THIS IS THE MOST UP-TO-DATE VERSION OF THE TARGET TABLE PART 1/2 (11/9/2023) - If this column experience loss of cooling this could cause material in the column to heat up and eventually build pressure in the column, leading to the weak point of the system rupturing - in this case the reflux drum.  If this occurred, acetic acid vapors would be released into the area potentially leading to a fire or inhalation hazard.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
The piece of equipment with the lowest MAWP in the system is the reflux drum 99C-D-333 (MAWP 24 psig).  

Assumptions:
- Maximum mass/relief rate based on feed rate to column for 1 hour: max rate over last year (2023) was ~1m3/min (liquid) --> 60 m3/hr = 53703 kg/hr = 118395 lb/hr
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (Mike James suggested 1 psig).  All acetic acid will vaporize.
- Storage temperature is the utility temperature which is the max temperature the system could experience (worst case)
- Discharge diameter was based on largest piping going to the reflux drum (8 in)
- The separation is acetic acid from unspecified high boilers.  Pure acetic acid was assumed due for highest vapor pressure (worst case).
- Release elevation is 2.3m (bottom of reflux drum - see drawing 99C-6-1129)
- Process area population density daytime - 3.5; nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Jimmy Nelson.
- Distance to non-process plant population was 40 m due to the river

Description: THIS IS THE MOST UP-TO-DATE VERSION OF THE TARGET TABLE PART 2/2 (11/9/2023) - If this column experience loss of cooling this could cause material in the column to heat up and eventually build pressure in the column, leading to the weak point of the system rupturing - in this case the reflux drum.  If this occurred, acetic acid liquid would be released into the area potentially leading to a fire or inhalation hazard.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
The piece of equipment with the lowest MAWP in the system is the reflux drum 99C-D-333 (MAWP 24 psig).  

Assumptions:
- Maximum mass/relief rate based on feed rate to column for 1 hour: max rate over last year (2023) was ~1m3/min (liquid) --> 60 m3/hr = 53703 kg/hr = 118395 lb/hr
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (Mike James suggested 1 psig).
- Storage temperature is the temperature of the liquid in the reflux drum, which is right under the boiling point of acetic acid (worst case)
- Catastrophic release of reflux drum material assumed (worst case)
- The separation is acetic acid from unspecified high boilers.  Pure acetic acid was assumed due for highest vapor pressure (worst case).
- Release elevation is 2.3m (bottom of reflux drum - see drawing 99C-6-1129)
- Contents of reflux drum --> 4344 gal (liquid full) --> 15521 kg
- Process area population density daytime - 3.5; nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Jimmy Nelson.
- Distance to non-process plant population was 40 m due to the river

- Secondary target table needs to be done considering liquid in reflux drum during release
      - Set temp/press to 117C / 0 psig (acetic acid stays liquid but is near boiling)
      - Determine if there's a dike the reflux drum material would fall into
      - Worst case is reflux drum being full, so use full volume as a liquid (convert to mass)

31.5.1: Loss of cooilng water to E-120; Higher temperature MEA to D-120A/B. Potential to overpressure D-120A/B with loss of containment if MAWP is exceeded; toxic and fire/explosion hazards

What are the potential consequences of NO or TOO LITTLE flow through the under flow piping?  

If the pumps fail for some reason, the bottom takeoff line is plugged, or the takeoff valve sticks closed or fails closed, the level in the base of the column will rise.  If this continues unmitigated, the potential exists to have liquid flow to the condenser and on to the reflux drum.  The base of the column could rupture.  Xylene could be released to the area.  If an ignition source is present, injuries to personnel and equipment damage could occur.

A LOPA (ID 908) was done for this scenario resulting in a differential of -1.5, indicating that a SIL1M high level interlock is needed.  JA-S02 acts on high base pressure to close feed valve HV-3556 and is SIL1 leaving -0.5 to close LOPA 908.

Flow info from analyses and DCS. Discharge at 207A feed height. Max. mass based on estimated mass in Amisol LOPAs.

NG flow control FC-1011 fails  (BPCS). Note: Flow/PD measurements 3 pcs in sis, median is supplied to BCPS 
Too low NG => too much oxygen => explosion in amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic realese/fire -> human injury.

Hand valve closed in line 10226-GMA-100-E63/10409-GMA-100/10227-GMA-100
No NG to gasifier=> too much oxygen => explosion in amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic release -> human injury

NG flow measurement (FX-1011) fails so that it is stuck to some value that makes sense (SIS). Note: Flow/PD measurements 3 pcs in sis, median is supplied to BCPS
Too low NG => too much oxygen => explosion in amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic release -> human injury

Nitrogen control FC-1014/-1034  fails at start-up: JB: startup pressure lower than nitrogen pressure, Does not happen during start-up, in normal operation possible
NG to nitrogen line  => too much oxygen => amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic release -> human injury

Malfunction on pressure control loop PC-1019 (valve fails open releasing the pressure from NG line)
Too low NG => too much oxygen =>  explosion in amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic release -> human injury

Power failure - No power from power station/network
1. LNG feed stop 
2. No NG to gasifier=> too much oxygen =>  explosion in amisol 207A (oxygen and amisol liquid react) - > amisol liquide leaks -> toxic release -> human injury (off site, Performitie)

Description: This is a copy of Kenzie's liquid overfill for WE-D-50 complete tank failure. I added the top head volume, 0.14 m3, to the tank volume she had used, 4.8 m3.
LOPATargetDiscussion: I experimented with people per 10,000 m2. There would have to be only 1 person to qualify for POE -2. However, that would be underrepresenting the risk, because moderate (ERPG-3) hits occupied buildings (daytime). See CG and XG tanks LOPAs for discussion on 10 people per 10,000 m2 occupancy.

A tube rupture in 14E-15A in the medium pressure stream could lead to overpressurization of the piping and its rupture if the available PSVs and PC-778 or PC-600 (flare valve) malfunctions.  This incident could allow CO and H2S gases to be released to the area.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
- The total flow is approximately 62,874 lb/h at 100°F (37.8°C).
- 1-hour long release is assumed: 62,874 lbs = 28519 kg.
- There are two 6" nozzles that tie the two bundles of tubes together. Worst case assumption is that both 6" nozzles are ruptured and use the combined area, which would be around a 9" diameter.
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (assumed 1 psig).
- Storage temperature is the max temperature the system could experience.
- Release elevation is ~20 ft (6 m). Refer to drawing GAS-14F-A-002 for elevation.
- Process population density daytime - 4.2, nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Kevin Hale.
- Distance to non-process plant population is 116 m (distance to river).

High flare rates during CTW failure or mitigated loss of IA (from flare design basis) cause rupture pin valves to open to the 42" flare, but the 16" piping in HCC-3 delivers too much flow from the 42" flare header to the HCC-3 12" flare tip, resulting in choked flow at the tip, flame lift-off, and horizontal release of unburned hydrocarbons into the flare area (B-88) near grade.  
Potential Consequences:
1)  flash fire 
2)  toxic impact 
3)  potential vapor cloud explosion <--- ruled out through Target Table modeling because gas cloud does not reach congested area
LOPATargetDiscussion:
RESULTS:
1)  Flash fire <-- determined to be Serious within 53 m (175 ft.) of the HCC-3 12" flare tip*, Minor building impact (B-70 or B-107) & no off-site impact
2)  Toxic impact <-- determined to be Serious for off-site impact at fence line** or Moderate for building impact (B-70 or B-107)
   Notes: 
      * The Serious fire impact around the flare is within the restricted access zone.
    ** The fence line is a remote location (woods/river) with a very low probability of people in the area.

BASIS:
Flow rates and pressures through 12" flare tip based on AFT hydraulic models from Engineering study: 
--- CTW failure (158 Kpph) 
--- Mitigated loss of IA (157 Kpph) 
--- Power failure scenario was lower flow rate (and not choked flow).

Inventory:  Assumed 1-hr supply of gas available as 1st guess.

Process area population density:  
--- Conservatively assumed 2 people in area for 1 hour in a 12-hour shift, even though most work is outside the area
--- The 10,000 m2 area for personnel basis ends just shy of pin valves (to the south)
--- Operators are outside this circle for rounds (just north of pin valves) or to replace a pin if one buckles (rare, 2 operators for 10-15 minutes)
--- Flow meter validation required environmentally occurs at the flow computer outside this circle 
--- Flow meter probe is within the area.  Conservatively assumed 7 people for 2 hours 1x/year (will pull probe if there is an issue, which is rare)
--- Because event occurs only when flare is in service, did not include maintenance present at the flare during turnarounds.

Buildings:  
--- Per Brandy Akin, B-107 headcount is 20 between 107 & 107-9, and 2 at 107-5, plus any PMD that might be in the area.  <-- Medium Occupancy Bldg.
--- No high occupancy buildings in the area.

Event frequency: 
--- Estimated as unlikely because design basis assumes flow rates occur simultaneously.  
--- Loss of utilities events have happened previously with no known loss of flame on the HCC-3 12" flare.

Note:
Previous SAFER modeling used higher flow rate of 278,739 lb/hr and determined Critical consequence.  Modeled in Target Table to compare PHAST to SAFER, and the results reduced scenario from Critical to Serious consequence for the previous high flow rate.  SAFER modeling used 100% propylene, but PHAST model is a mixture, so the comparison is not the same basis for toxicity.

If all the mag oxide is added at once before agitation is started, the temperature of the batch could rise to 225F. The potential exists to overpressure the tank leading to a release of hot process material resulting in equipment damage and possible injury to personnel. Tank failure target table.
Process steps: Fill with flash acid (72% acetic acid) to ~72". Add water to about 35-37% acid. Relief calc assumes instant reaction rate once agitation is started. Target tables assumes that all the acid is consumed, the final acid is 4-8%. Storage pressure is MAWP plus 10%. Temp is bubble point. Tanks are in B-82 west tank farm.

Tube Break in E-21, Instantaneous Failure of C-11 or E-21 due to static head in C-2: Instant loss of all contents, All contents vented as liquid.

A tube rupture in 14E-21 could result in high pressure in 14E-21 shellside/14C-11. This would result in a release of methanol, CO2, and CO to the operating area. This incident could release cold methanol and process gases to the area that could lead to a fire/explosion scenario and the gases could threaten the health of personnel in a large portion of the plant.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
- Composition of C2 column holdup based on 2004 LINDE HMB stream 14-47 (normal bottom flow from C-2) mixed with tube rupture flow which is based on the composition of Linde HMB stream 14-124 (tube side feed to E-21). The premise of this assumption is that the side draw loop via E-8, E-21, and C-11 continues to operate as normal with the composition of the material entering the system being mixed in at a rate equal to the tube rupture flow.
- Bulk temperature = -36F (-37.8C)
- If completely filled, C2 would hold at least 40,500 gallons of material and C-11 would hold an additional. If the failure occurred in C-11 or E-21, the total loss of material would be on the order of 47,000 gallons (density 7.09 lb/gal)
- Catastrophic failure is assumed.
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (assumed 1 psig).
- Release elevation is ~20 ft (6 m). Refer to drawing GAS-14F-A-002 for elevation.
- Process population density daytime - 4.2, nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Kevin Hale.
- Distance to non-process plant population is 116 m (distance to river).

Description:
Tube Break in E-8, Instantaneous Failure of C-11 or E-21 due to static head in C-2, Instant Loss of all contents, All contents vented as liquid.

A tube rupture in 14E-8 could allow high pressure methanol to enter the shell of this vessel. This would result in a release of methanol, CO2, and CO to the operating area. This incident could release cold methanol and process gases to the area that could lead to a fire/explosion scenario and the gases could threaten the health of personnel in a large portion of the plant.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
-Composition of C2 column holdup based on 2004 LINDE HMB stream 14-47 (normal bottom flow from C-2) mixed with tube rupture flow which is based on the composition of Linde HMB stream 14-120 (tube side feed to E-8).  The premise of this assumption is that the side draw loop via E-8, E-21, and C-11 continues to operate as normal with the composition of the material entering the system being mixed in at a rate equal to the tube rupture flow.
- Bulk temperature = -47°F (-43.9C)
- If completely filled, C2 would hold at least 40,500 gallons of material and C11 would hold an additional.  If the failure occurred in C-11 or E-21, the total loss of material would be on the order of 47,000 gallons (density 7.08 lb/gal).  
- Catastrophic failure is assumed.
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (assumed 1 psig).
- Release elevation is ~20 ft (6 m). Refer to drawing GAS-14F-A-002 for elevation.
- Process population density daytime - 4.2, nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Kevin Hale.
- Distance to non-process plant population is 116 m (distance to river).

Case 12 from relief calc - maximum addition rate of MgO leading to heat generation and vaporization of tank contents. Relief through PSV target table.
Process steps: Fill with flash acid (72% acetic acid) to ~72". Add water to about 35-37% acid. Since 92% of the MgO has to be added to heat the tank to the bubble point, this target table uses the final acid amount, 4-8%. Temp is bubble point at MAWP + 10%. Tanks are in B-82 west tank farm.

Failure of the river water supply due to human error, valve failure, air supply failure or solenoid failure could result in hot acetic acid, ketene, and other gases passing through the first section of the Furnace 5 condenser and causing failure due to high temperature.  This could result in a release of hot acetic acid and ketene vapors into the operating area, causing injury.  If an ignition source is present, a fire could result, causing equipment damage and injury to personnel.

Description:
MJ - FIX POOL AREA.

Failure of 7R-C-101 due to liquid overfill, release of 29.4% ammonia solution in water, located inside B-7R, 4th Floor - Impact to personnel on production floor only.  results for this model should only consider the "on-site" results category.  the results for building and offsite should be ignored.  modeling for building and offsite impact are based on an "indoor release model", performed separately.

actual release temperature is 30 deg C.  the temperature input here is artificially lowered such that the ideal VLE calculated vapor pressure matches the actual vapor pressure of the mixture at the release conditions.

If those valves are fully open they will not only have gas, but also liquid going to the 4850 storage tank. The liquid methanol will flash in the 90°C collector. A methanol vapor cloud will be released.
LOPATargetDiscussion: DN15 with a leak of 7 mm (0.3 inch)
LOPAID: H10-13087 and H10-13069 are fully open.

Description:
If the temperature in  Acetic Acid /Anhydride Tank 23B exceeds the flashpoint of acetic anhydride (between 5-20% acetic anhydride), a flammable mixture can form in the vapor space within the tank since there is no nitrogen blanketing. If an ignition source is present, a deflagration could occur in Tank 23B, causing equipment damage releasing acetic / anhydride mixture and injury due to POOL FIRE. 

Old target table assigned a consequence ranking of severity to be Serious with no conditional modifiers. Because a deflagration must occur to lead to a toxicity exposure, the conditional modifier for POI was still included.)

Total tank volume = 1337 gallons
Water infiltration into 30A during scrubber cleaning

Description:
just a copy to see if this one returns.  Failure of 7R-C-101 due to liquid overfill, release of 29.4% ammonia solution in water, located inside B-7R, 4th Floor - Impact to personnel on production floor only.  results for this model should only consider the "on-site" results category.  the results for building and offsite should be ignored.  modeling for building and offsite impact are based on an "indoor release model", performed separately.

actual release temperature is 30 deg C.  the temperature input here is artificially lowered such that the ideal VLE calculated vapor pressure matches the actual vapor pressure of the mixture at the release conditions.
L-2241 malfunctions low while reading high. Rupture of TK-220, release of process materials with potential for personnel injury due to chemical exposure or fire.
test
Gaia-mallinnus ammoniakkivuoto, 50 mm
Pieni ammoniakkivuoto, 12 mm - laippa/letkuvuoto

Description:
Thermal expansion due to blocked in piping from the truck unloading station to the sphere could overpressure the pipe and cause a loss of containment. 

Notes: Release location/elevation will be at a location between the truck and the sphere. Leak diameter is 0.6" per alkylamines guidelines for modeling a leak in 3/4" pipe. Pressure comes from MAWP of 300# flange. **Running model at a few different pressures to model a 5-10 minute release.

Loss of cooling in RA-E-20/VD-E-22 allows for process material from RA-C-03 to enter RA-C-59 and RA-C-30A at reactor temperature (110-170degC). Mixture flashes upon entering settling tank, which could lead to vessel rupture and release of flammable mixture from reactor and hydrogen to the operating area.

Mixture of 2% caustic, 3% catalyst slurry, 31% water, <1% aldehyde (MPK uses acetaldehyde, MIAK uses isobutyraldehyde), 36% acetone and 32% MPK or other ketones. 3385 gal capacity in RA-C-30A

Description: B-73 Tank Farm Group 3 tank 131 HOAc

MJ - updated occupancy.  Per Laura Perez - "PL said daytime occupancy can be as high as 100 people but only about 25 people at nighttime. They exclusively do storage tank loading at nighttime since there’s a nearby unloading station that could be a chemical compatibility issue that operates exclusively in the daytime."


The occupancy here would be 25 people across the whole area of the impact zone.  If I’m on the right target table, it’s showing the impacted area to be 260,285 m2.  So, the average population density would be 25 people / 260,285 m2, then scaled up to 10,000 m2.

25 / 260,285 * 10,000 = 0.96 people per 10,000 m2.

MH-D-01/02 has 30,000 gal storage capacity of 30%wt aqueous ammonia. Trailer is approx. 6,000 gal.

Mixture of 2% caustic, 3% catalyst slurry, 31% water, <1% aldehyde (MPK uses acetaldehyde, MIAK uses isobutyraldehyde), 36% acetone and 32% MPK or other ketones. Reactor operating mostly liquid full (there is a small vapor space) at 400psi and high temperature.
Temperature set point varies by product:
MIBK: 160-180degC
MIAK: 90-105degC
MPK: 80degC

roughly 305m to the river (consider additional credit), next closest boundary is with lincoln street at 355m

MJ - 25 C - support - A tube rupture in 14E-8 could allow high pressure methanol to enter the shell of this vessel. This would result in a release of methanol, CO2, and CO to the operating area. This incident could release cold methanol and process gases to the area that could lead to a fire/explosion scenario and the gases could threaten the health of personnel in a large portion of the plant. The failure considered is that column C-2 fills up and C-11, which is the lowest of the vessels in this system, bursts and the contents of C-2 are lost via 14E-21. - COPY - 03/15/2024 11:06:44 -04:00

If one sphere is out of service, site would allow inventory to increase from managed 500 tons to 1000 tons. For overfill/overpressure to occur in one sphere, would have to unload additional >1000 tons in a single sphere. Overfill would first go to the recompressor accumulators. WF 3602 - flare-out - flammable environment around flare

What are the potential consequences if the temperature due to process conditions goes ABOVE the safe operating limits?

If the temperature becomes too high due to flame flashback from the Flare or Furnaces 27 and 28, the B-7R Sump Tank vessel could become weakened and fail releasing fire to the area resulting in further equipment damage and injury to personnel.

Model based on assumption that hot gas melts hole in vessel, then Sump Gas at normal conditions flows thru hole into area, causing flash fire and potential for VCE.

TARGET TABLE FOR AP-52 CURRENT VESSEL - RATE BASED. This target table exists to provide the severity of a failure of this vessel as it currently exists in the field. AP-52 does not meet inspection code, repair code, or construction code and failure of its support legs is imminent. Critical failure on coils around the support pads/braces would lead to tipping over of the vessel. The structural support legs are welded to rotten and brittle coils.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
-There are (3) feeds to this tank - (1) and (2) are virgin EG feeds at approximately pure EG and 38C, (3) is a feed from Column AL-01 underflow which is at 180C, but cooled via jacketed pipe before entering AP-52.
-Streams (1) and (2) flow rates are worst case 5,000 lb/h combined, and stream (3) worst case flow is 9,000 lb/h.
-AP-52 is controlled around 85C, but the average overflow temperature is 100C, but can get up to 200C.
-Failure of the vessel is assumed to relieve the entire contents of the vessel in addition to 30 mins equivalent to the inlet flow rate (per Vessel Failure updated guidance)
    -Vessel capacity is 570 gal (at 100C, this is 2277 kg of EG), Maximum inlet flow is 14,000 lb/h (6350 kg/h). To relieve the entire contents of the vessel plus the inlet 
    flow rate for a duration of 30 minutes would be a total relieved mass of 5452 kg (2277kg + 30 mins of 6350kg/h). To relieve this total amount in 30 mins, the relief 
    rate is 10,904 kg/h (24,039 lb/h).
-AP-52 is located on the 6th floor of B15L07 (~100 ft, 30.48 m elevation)
-Occupancy information provided by Ian Kilcoyne within 10,000 m2 radius:
    -3 operators 24/7
    -2 material movement operators 3 hours per 12-hour shift
    -Using the occupancy tool spreadsheet, this equates to a daytime occupancy of 3.5 and nighttime occupancy of 3.5
-Occupied buildings considered: B15L07 as medium occupancy due to maintenance shop and B15L01 as high occupancy due to administrative building.

Description: TARGET TABLE FOR AP-52 NEW VESSEL. This target table exists to provide the severity of a failure for a new vessel.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
-There are (3) feeds to this tank - (1) and (2) are virgin EG feeds at approximately pure EG and 38C, (3) is a feed from Column AL-01 underflow which is at 180C, but cooled via jacketed pipe before entering AP-52.
-Streams (1) and (2) flow rates are worst case 5,000 lb/h combined, and stream (3) worst case flow is 9,000 lb/h.
-AP-52 is controlled around 85C, but the average overflow temperature is 100C, but can get up to 200C.
-For new vessel, inlet rate was assumed at 14,000 lb/h. Vessel capacity is 570 gal (at 100C, this is 2277 kg of EG).
-Maximum mass considered was full tank contents (2277 kg) plus maximum fill rate for 30 mins (6350 kg).
-AP-52 is located on the 6th floor of B15L07 (~100 ft, 30.48 m elevation)
-Occupancy information provided by Ian Kilcoyne within 10,000 m2 radius:
    -3 operators 24/7
    -2 material movement operators 3 hours per 12-hour shift
    -Using the occupancy tool spreadsheet, this equates to a daytime occupancy of 9.5 and nighttime occupancy of 3.5

Tube Break in E-21, Hole Opens to pass ONLY the flow added due to the tube rupture, All contents vented as liquid.

A tube rupture in 14E-21 could result in high pressure in 14E-21 shellside/14C-11. This would result in a release of methanol, CO2, and CO to the operating area. This incident could release cold methanol and process gases to the area that could lead to a fire/explosion scenario and the gases could threaten the health of personnel in a large portion of the plant.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
- Since this scenario considers loss of material at C-11/E-21 specifically as the result of opening a flow path only large enough to pass the required excess flow, it was felt that the stream composition of the side draw would better match the intent of the LOPA refinements.  Composition of stream based on 2004 LINDE HMB stream 14-41 (normal flow from E-21 to C-11) plus the stream 14-28 (normal flow from C-18 to C-11) mixed with tube rupture flow which is based on the composition of Linde HMB stream 14-124 (tube side feed to E-21).  The premise of this assumption is that the side draw loop via E-8, E-21, and C-11 continues to operate as normal with the composition of the material entering the system being mixed in at a rate equal to the tube rupture flow.
- Bulk temperature = -21F (-29.4C)
- If completely filled, C2 would hold at least 40,500 gallons of material and C-11 would hold an additional. If the failure occurred in C-11 or E-21, the total loss of material would be on the order of 47,000 gallons.
- The tube rupture flow is ~300 gpm (density 7.12 lb/gal).
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (assumed 1 psig).
- Release elevation is ~20 ft (6 m). Refer to drawing GAS-14F-A-002 for elevation.
- Process population density daytime - 4.2, nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Kevin Hale.
- Distance to non-process plant population is 116 m (distance to river).

The premise of this assumption is that the side draw loop via E-8, E-21, and C-11 continues to operate as normal with the composition of the material entering the system being mixed in at a rate equal to the tube rupture flow.

Tube Break in E-5 (1 of 2), Instantaneous Failure of C-11 or E-21 due to static head in C-2, Instant Loss of all contents, All contents vented as liquid.

If a tube rupture in 14E-5, high pressure methanol could enter the shell side of 14E-5, the shell of this vessel and/or associated piping could rupture. Dirty cold methanol could be spilled to the ground. H2S gases that would be evolved could be a threat to health of personnel in multiple zones of the plant. The methanol could ignite and cause a localized damage to the process.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
-Composition of C2 column holdup based on 2004 LINDE HMB stream 14-47 (normal bottom flow from C-2) mixed with tube rupture flow which is based on the composition of Linde HMB stream 14-110 (one of two tube side feeds to E-5).  The premise of this assumption is that the side draw loop via E-8, E-21, and C-11 stops at the base of C-11 due to high pressure in E-5 (due to the tube rupture) however the liquid flow is still returned to C-2 via the vapor path as C-11 overfill (same basic overall result as a break in E-21 or E-8) and the composition of the material entering the system being mixed in at a rate equal to the tube rupture flow.
- Bulk temperature = -29°F (-33.9C)
- If completely filled, C2 would hold at least 40,500 gallons of material and C11 would hold an additional.  If the failure occurred in C-11 or E-21, the total loss of material would be on the order of 47,000 gallons (7.15 lb/gal).
- Catastrophic failure is assumed.
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (assumed 1 psig).
- Release elevation is ~20 ft (6 m). Refer to drawing GAS-14F-A-002 for elevation.
- Process population density daytime - 4.2, nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Kevin Hale.
- Distance to non-process plant population is 116 m (distance to river).

High level in Tank #12 could result in overpressure of the tank due to static head of the liquid (MAWP is 2.5 psig and the tank is rated to be liquid full).  

Flash points tested on two samples from tank 12 in 1999 (DDL-6845-27 - in TEDP2004 Rev F folder) with 0.94% solvent and 1.012% IPA were 87.1 and 87.9F. See also the Coverage Discussion document in TEDP2112 Rev D folder for reference to 2009-2010 sampling that showed >1% flammables and flash point 75F. There is also a document on the Consequence Modeling CT sharepoint called "IPA_flashpoints" that tested samples from 1% to 3.5% solvent and 0% to 12.5% acid. These tests show higher flash points on 1% acid samples than the 1999 data.

Flow rate per Zach Gardner: Worst flow into tank 12 is 220 gpm; this is more liquid coming with slurry than normal, with both precipitators running. 60 gpm is from each precipitator + 40-50 gpm repulping acid fed into each bird centrifuge.
Temperature from RA:PPT_TT_CC_239_PMP.PV and RA:PPT_TT_TK_D12.PV. Temp does go higher than 95F in PI data but 95F was used in E reval CC (node 73) LOPA. (Note - the spikes are very short so when PI data is over a long time period, you can't see the spikes higher than 95F.)
Composition from the E reval, the composition data was provided by Zach Gardner per Natalie Rogers.
The square footage of the 2nd floor room is 8830 ft2 (820 m2). 273 m2 per person for 3 people on avg.

Description: Oulu - Formic acid column 5000

If the guided wave level transmitter fails to function properly, overfilling of the reactors could occur with material flowing through the relief paths on the three reactors.  Subsequent pressure surge from either the catalyst feed pumps or from full vessel effect, generated by centrifugal pumps (inertial energy), could cause the relief system to activate releasing a mixture of MAK, n-butyraldehyde, acetone, hydrogen, and possibly catalyst to QA-C-38 emergency vent separator. If the relief systems is inadequate, reactors 1,2 and/or 3 could be overpressured and could rupture. This failure could lead to the release of flammable reactor contents. A significant hydrogen release could occur. A fire and/or explosion could occur resulting in significant equipment damage and injuries to personnel.

If the guided wave level transmitter fails to function properly, overfilling of the reactors could occur with material flowing through the relief paths on the three reactors.  Subsequent pressure surge from either the catalyst feed pumps or from full vessel effect, generated by centrifugal pumps (inertial energy), could cause the relief system to activate releasing a mixture of MAK, n-butyraldehyde, acetone, hydrogen, and possibly catalyst to QA-C-38 emergency vent separator. If the relief systems is inadequate, reactors 1,2 and/or 3 could be overpressured and could rupture. This failure could lead to the release of flammable reactor contents. A significant hydrogen release could occur. A fire and/or explosion could occur resulting in significant equipment damage and injuries to personnel.

Low level in QA-C-03 could result in hydrogen blowing straight through to QA-C-31 settling tank.  If the relief system fails to operate properly, QA-C-31 could be overpressured and could rupture. This failure could lead to the release of flammable contents. A significant hydrogen release could occur. A fire and/or explosion could occur resulting in significant equipment damage and injuries to personnel.

If manual valves are closed in the piping from QA-C-03 through QA-E-20 to QA-C-30 are closed or the level valve or block valve fail closed, overfilling of the reactors could occur with material flowing through the relief path up to rupture disks. Subsequent pressure surge from either the catalyst feed pumps or from full vessel effect, generated by centrifugal pumps (inertial energy), could cause the rupture disk to activate. The relief valves could subsequently be activated releasing a mixture of MAK, n-butyraldehyde, acetone, hydrogen, and possibly catalyst, to QA-C-38 emergency vent separator.  This failure could lead to the release of flammable reactor contents. A significant hydrogen release could occur. A fire and/or explosion could occur resulting in significant equipment damage and injuries to personnel.
Acetone Overfill 244A-9T-647 QA-C-01

If the pressure relief devices on the shells of QA-E-20A/B are not properly designed or fail to function properly, the potential exists to fail the exchangers leading to release of the contents into the operating area. Injuries to personnel could result from the failure of the vessel and/or exposure to flammables and/or hydrogen.  A fire and/or explosion could result leading to additional equipment damage and/or injuries to personnel.  The release could add fuel to an existing fire.

Tube rupture is a credible overpressurization scenario due to the differential between the tubeside operating pressure and the shellside pressure rating (150 psig).

Overfill of A-tank. Tank only rated for 6" w.c. (0.217 psig) and no liquid above the head seam. Vessel rupture is the worst case.
Dike around the tank has sufficient capacity to hold the entire tank contents.
Tank volume is 20,050 gal (75.9 m3) from PID. Area of the tank is 18.68 m2 due to 16ft diameter. Dike area is about 75m2. pool area is 75-18.68= 56.32 m2
Tank temperature is ambient. Hottest summer temp is around 90F

If this system is deadheaded, the feed pumps can overpressure the reflux drum, which is the weak point in the system. Pumps have a deadhead of 73 psig which is greater than the reflux drum MAWP of 24 psig. If this occurs, material would be released into the area potentially leading a fire or inhalation hazard.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
The piece of equipment with the lowest MAWP in the system is the reflux drum 99C-D-333 (MAWP 24 psig). 

Assumptions: 
- Maximum mass/relief rate based on feed rate to column for 1 hour: max rate over last year (2023) was ~1m3/min (liquid) --> 60 m3/hr = 53703 kg/hr = 118395 lb/hr
- Storage pressure is pressure on release (Mike James suggested 1 psig).
- Storage temperature is the temperature of the liquid in the reflux drum, which is right under the boiling point of acetic acid (worst case)
- Catastrophic release of reflux drum material assumed (worst case)
- The separation is acetic acid from unspecified high boilers.  Pure acetic acid was assumed due for highest vapor pressure (worst case).
- Release elevation is 2.3m (bottom of reflux drum - see drawing 99C-6-1129)
- Contents of reflux drum --> 4344 gal (liquid full) --> 15521 kg
- Process area population density daytime - 3.5; nighttime - 1.5. Based on occupancy worksheet discussion with Jimmy Nelson.
- Distance to non-process plant population was 40 m due to the river

For liquid in reflux drum during release:
      - Set temp/press to 117C / 0 psig (acetic acid stays liquid but is near boiling)
      - Determine if there's a dike the reflux drum material would fall into
      - Worst case is reflux drum being full, so use full volume as a liquid (convert to mass)

R300 Overpressure scenario - flammable mixture in the Propionic acid reactor.  Increased O2 content in the reactor reaching the flammable region that could lead to  internal explosion/deflagration.   Conditions that can lead to excess O2 content are: loss or low Priopionaldehyde feed flow, excess air input/air flow rate, loss of reactor circulation due to low reactor level, low reactor temperature, deactivated catalyst.
LOPATargetDiscussion: Liquid phase oxidation reaction.  Propionaldehyde is reacted with excess oxygen [air] in the presence of a water soluable catalyst to form Propionic Acid; Acetic Acid is the principal coproduct.  The vessel operates at approximately 1 psig and 208 F and the heat of reaction is removed by circulation coolers E-302 and E-323.  R-300 O2 concentration critical safety limit is 9.4% O2 (Interlock S/d at 7.4%).  R300 MAWP is 80 psig at 400F.  PSV-R-300 set pressure is 65 psig.  R-300 has an upper section (5 ft diameter, 25 ft height, semi-ellipt head for 500 ft^3)  and lower section (4 ft diameter, 54.63 ft height, semi-ellipt head for 690 ft^3) with total volume 1190 ft^3.  Reactor runs 60%full.

3811/3812 säiliön hönkälinja jäässä
1. Jos syöttö on MH2:lta päiväsäiliöihin 3811/3812, voi säiliön paine täyttövaiheessa nousta 4700 kolonnin paineeseen 2 barg (reitin tarve alle 10% tehtaan käynnissäoloajasta)
2. Säiliön 3811/3812 ylempi suunnittelupaine ei tiedossa, säiliön suunnittelupaine voi ylittyä yli 2,0-kertaisesti
3. Säiliön repeää alasaumasta
4. Max. noin 50 m3 82-84% muurahaishappoa virtaa ympäristöön
5. Myrkyllisyysvaikutus
6. Henkilövahinko

3811/3812 MH1:n MH-päiväsäiliön perustuskiinnitykset ruostuneet
1. Säiliön helma voi nyrjähtää ja säiliö voi liikkua tai kaatua

3. Muurahaishappovuoto ympäristöön (turva-altaan reuna lähellä säiliötä)
4. Myrkyllisyysvaikutus
5. Henkilövahinko

3. Jos kolonnin sisäpuolella syttymä (esim. johtamattomien sisuskalujen staattisensähkön vuoksi), räjähdys

4. Henkilövahinko

3. Kolonni 4700/5000/5700/6000 täyttyy

6. Vuoto
7. Myrkyllisyysvaikutus

Description:
MJ - Modeling as elevated release.  Bridge receptor as "Personnel at elevation".  Acetone released in pipe rack below bridge elevation.

Pressure decreased to 0.043938388 psig to allow for flow rate at 2" diam.

Overwriting med occ bldg to view impact at bridge height.  Google Earth Plot for this elevation will determine if Critical is appropriate.

1b. Edited 26Apr2024 for Sep Col    and   DMA Col max flow into D-67025A/B DMA Check Tank (requires Sep Col and DMA Col at PSV set pressure of 250 psig vs normal operating pressure of 80-100 psig to be able to lift DMA Check Tank PSV). Flowrate = max flow through both 1" Fisher EZ FV-6714 and FV-6283 (both with Cv=13.2) 2 x 62.1 gpm = 124.2 gpm = 38,358 lbs/hr = 1450 kg for 5-minute release.  Release elevation 10.7 m.  PSV set at 200 psig and discharges to atm with short vertical stack. Composition anhydrous DMA liquefied gas. Release from PSV is flashing liquid.  Exit temperature = NBP. - COPY - 02/12/2024 18:27:34 -05:00 - COPY - 03/15/2024 14:41:25 -04:00 - COPY - 04/26/2024 16:34:13 -04:00

MJ - Support - Internal deflagration modeled in SuperChems.  Final pressure determined to be 129 psig in the vessel.  This is between 1.3 and 2x MAWP (80 psig), so modeling 0.5-in hole at bottom of vessel.

R300 Overpressure scenario - flammable mixture in the Propionic acid reactor.  Increased O2 content in the reactor reaching the flammable region that could lead to  internal explosion/deflagration.   Conditions that can lead to excess O2 content are: loss or low Priopionaldehyde feed flow, excess air input/air flow rate, loss of reactor circulation due to low reactor level, low reactor temperature, deactivated catalyst.
LOPA Scenario - 308.3, Potential vessel failure - loss of containment, High Pressure due to loss of cooling to E-67192, MMA Check Tank Cooler.
LOPATargetDiscussion: This scenario gives a catastrophic on-site consequence based on 3 people in the operating area (10,000 m2) at the time of the incident.  The Target Table 2.0 extrapolates this ratio 1 person / 3,333 m2 for the entire Impact Area, which would be equivalent to 153 impacted people sitewide.  This is more than the people that on average would be on-site (<32 is closer to expected occupancy).  Therefore, the consequence will be downgraded to critical.  This is consistent with consequence specified by PHA team.

Description: Loss of acetic acid flow into AA-C-06/07 and AB-C-06/07 due to anhydride contamination in Tank 23B:  If AA-C-06/07 and AB-C-06/07 lose reaction of acetic acid with ketene simultaneously with both Furnace 27 and 28 in operation, ketene breakthrough will occur into the downstream liquid ring vacuum pump system and AA-C-08 scrubber and AA-C-38 separator pot.  Kinetic modeling from WWE&C concludes a loss of all 4 scrubbers with 27 and 28 in operation could result in a maximum temp of 325 oC in AA-C-08 (MAWT is 177 oC) and 490 oC in AA-C-38 (MAWT is 149 oC) separator pot.  Exceeding vessel MAWTs could result in vessel failure releasing ketene and vessel contents into the operating area.  This could result in personnel injury onsite and offsite.

Loss of acetic acid flow into AA-C-06/07 and AB-C-06/07 due to anhydride contamination in Tank 23B:  If AA-C-06/07 and AB-C-06/07 lose reaction of acetic acid with ketene simultaneously with both Furnace 27 and 28 in operation, ketene breakthrough will occur into the downstream liquid ring vacuum pump system and AA-C-08 scrubber and AA-C-38 separator pot.  Kinetic modeling from WWE&C concludes a loss of all 4 scrubbers with 27 and 28 in operation could result in a maximum temp of 325 oC in AA-C-08 (MAWT is 177 oC) and 490 oC in AA-C-38 (MAWT is 149 oC) separator pot.  Exceeding vessel MAWTs could result in vessel failure releasing ketene and vessel contents into the operating area.  This could result in personnel injury onsite and offsite. - COPY - 07/23/2024 17:07:04 -04:00

Description: Overfill and rupture of Tank 402

Overfill of 34-C-13 from 34-C-10 due to inadequate liquid relief in 34-C-10. MAWP is 55 psig
Full volume of the refining column is 6565 gal or 24.85 m3
at normal operating temperatures 250F or 121C
assuming 1/2" leak because new vessel rupture guidance of pneumatic overpressure less than 200% MAWP 
Feed composition of 34-C-10

Overfill and rupture of Tank 401. This scenario may not be credible and was used to establish a baseline

Note, this case was run to assess potential consequences in the event the relief device is not adequate/fails/is not properly installed. The existing devices are adequate for relief through PSV-D401-1 and PSV-D-401-2. The relief calculation notes that the material would likely flow to the vent header.

Description: Liquid overfill of slurry mix tanks with methanol from supply header (Node 20)

Because of this, only one model was run with the center of the diked area as the coordinates.

Tyhjennyslinjan 3355-VLA-50-16H200 sähkösaattovika -> DN50 laippavuoto ulkona
1. Erotinta 600E tyhjennetään kerran vuorossa. Korkeapaineista fluidia voi päästä PN16-luokan putkeen
2. Jos putki jäätyy, putken  suunnitteluarvo PN16 voi ylittyä yli 2-kertaisesti
3. Putkirikko
4. Nestettä ja mahdollisesti synteesikaasua vuotaa ulos
5. Henkilövahinko, myrkyllisyysvaikutus

490E viemärilinja jäässä -> DN50 laippavuoto ulkona
1. Erotin 490E ei tyhjene
2. Pinta nousee pitkän ajan kuluessa (PSA:lta ja membralta tulee vähän lauhteita)
3. Talvella myös 490E voi jäätyä
4. 600E:stä tulevan fluidin paine voi ylittää putken suunnitteluarvon PN16 yli 2-kertaisesti sekä erottimen 490E suunnitteluarvon 
5. Putki/laiterikko
6. Nestettä ja mahdollisesti synteesikaasua vuotaa ulos
7. Henkilövahinko, myrkyllisyysvaikutus

2. Suunnittelupaine voi ylittyä
3. Pieni laippavuoto
4. Keskisuuri vuoto
5. Henkilövahinko, tulipalo (onsite)

Description: LOPA Scenario - 715.1, TMA Storage Tank Pump Suction Line Leak. 6" Line, so assume 0.6" diameter hole per AA LOPA Guidelines. - COPY - 09/26/2024 09:34:10 -04:00

65 deg C (loss of cooling)

98% meoh 2% water

modeling 15 min worth of flow

per Alexander Niccum email - 9/25/2024

-	For the three Tetrashield grades we will produce on X-Line, the highest amount of methanol that is being refined is 62 lbs./min.
-	The MPPE-900 scrubber can only condense 2.7 lbs./min of methanol based on the minimum required flow of 2 gpm, so the scrubber will only have a small impact.
-	That being said, the scenario references that the overhead condenser (XL-21) would still be operational. XL-21 can condense 40 lbs./min based on process trend data over the last 5 years.  

Based on these findings, I would recommend using 20 lbs./min to model the loss of reflux scenario.
LOPA Scenario - 635.1, DMA Storage Sphere Pump Suction Line Leak.  Per AA LOPA guidelines a 0.6" diameter leak is used.
LOPATargetDiscussion: FINAL TT20 for this scenario.

Scen1: Flow control loop FC-6236/5636 failure. No water flow to 104A/154A spray scrubber -> Syngas leak

Flow control loop FC-6236/5636 failure. No water flow to 104A/154A spray scrubber -> Syngas leak

4. Syngas leak (most probably in piping) 
5. Toxic release
6. Human injury

2. Level decreases in 105A/155A, if production rate is small (not enough water condensated from syngas) and not enough water to 104A/154A
3 Temperature (app. 250 C) rise downstream (scrubber 105A) 
4. equipment failures possible, if design temperature exceeded in long term. Not sure if design temperature is exceeded. Design temps 280 C for pipe after spray scrubber, 105A/155A 180 C and 160 C for sootwater piping.
5. Possible damage of scrubber 105A/155A or piping
6. Syngas leak (most probably in piping) 
7. Toxic release
8. Human injury

3. Possible damage of scrubber 105A/155A or piping
4. Syngas leak (from 105A/155A) 
5. Toxic release
6. Human injury (onsite SER, ohjaamo MOD)

Pump 167P/157P/107P malfunction -> Syngas leak
1. 1. No additional water to water circulation
2. Level decreases in 105A/155A, if production rate is small (not enough water condensated from syngas) and not enough water to 104A/154A
3 Temperature (app. 250 C) rise downstream (scrubber 105A) 
4. equipment failures possible, if design temperature exceeded in long term. Not sure if design temperature is exceeded. Design temps 280 C for pipe after spray scrubber, 105A/155A 180 C and 160 C for sootwater piping.
5. Possible damage of scrubber 105A/155A or piping
6. Syngas leak (most probably in piping) 
7. Toxic release
8. Human injury

Heat trace failure in stand by process -> Syngas leak

2. Additional river water leak in start up of stand by process. Addition river water to surroundings
2. Addition river water system empties gradually
3. Synthesis gas leak outside at process area
4. Toxic release
5. Human injury (control room MOD, Onsite inhalation and flash fire SER)
OR

Description:
What are the potential consequences of NO or TOO LITTLE flow through the under flow piping?  

If the pumps fail for some reason, the bottom takeoff line is plugged, or the takeoff valve sticks closed or fails closed, the level in the base of the column will rise.  If this continues unmitigated, the potential exists to have liquid flow to the condenser and on to the reflux drum.  The base of the column could rupture.  Xylene could be released to the area.  If an ignition source is present, injuries to personnel and equipment damage could occur.

A LOPA (ID 908) was done for this scenario resulting in a differential of -1.5, indicating that a SIL1M high level interlock is needed.  JA-S02 acts on high base pressure to close feed valve HV-3556 and is SIL1 leaving -0.5 to close LOPA 908.

Description: V2516 fails

1" HTM leak
Flow from strainer connects to evaporator pumps at the recycle tank which could backflow into the strainers. Potential to cause high level in the spray condenser.
Spray condenser and R7 are not rated to be liquid full. The consequence of overfilling these vessels is likely a fail in the support structure resulting in a 1" or 2" HTM leak.
N-line 4th floor occupancy is 3 people in the daytime. y-line gear pumps are on the 3rd floor which is less occupied. 
Curbing area is 760 ft3 or 5600 gals
Need estimate of volume of a HTM loop
Closest offsite is John B Dennis
HTM temp is 650F from pump spec. Pump PSV set at 175 psig. pressure at the R7 equipment is 172 psig.
HTM is VP-1

Flow from strainer connects to evaporator pumps at the recycle tank which could backflow into the strainers. Potential to cause high level in the spray condenser.
Spray condenser and R7 are not rated to be liquid full. The consequence of overfilling these vessels is likely a fail in the support structure resulting in a 1" or 2" HTM leak.

1. Erotinta 600E tyhjennetään kerran vuorossa. Korkeapaineista fluidia voi päästä PN16-luokan putkeen
2. Jos putki jäätyy, putken  suunnitteluarvo PN16 voi ylittyä yli 2-kertaisesti
3. Putkirikko
4. Nestettä ja mahdollisesti synteesikaasua vuotaa ulos
5. Henkilövahinko, myrkyllisyysvaikutus

490E viemärilinja jäässä -> Vuoto DN50:stä putkesta
1. Erotin 490E ei tyhjene
2. Pinta nousee pitkän ajan kuluessa (PSA:lta ja membralta tulee vähän lauhteita)
3. Talvella myös 490E voi jäätyä
4. 600E:stä tulevan fluidin paine voi ylittää putken suunnitteluarvon PN16 yli 2-kertaisesti sekä erottimen 490E suunnitteluarvon 
5. Putki/laiterikko
6. Nestettä ja mahdollisesti synteesikaasua vuotaa ulos
7. Henkilövahinko, myrkyllisyysvaikutus

Description: LOPA Scenarios 13.1 / 13.2 / 13.3: Release of NH3/MeOH due to liquid carryover from MeOH Vaporizer into Gas Fired Heater (GFH) resulting in catastrophic tube failure of 4" tube inside GFH.  Ignition is likely, but model for both Flash Fire and Inhalation.  Assume failure point at the lowest elevation of tube in furnace (2 m) and assume that furnace walls/refractory prevent significant horizontal jetting (release is vertical orientation).  There is sufficient NH3 superheat to bring the mixture to the bp of MeOH (341 F / 172 C) at normal pressure (315 psig).  Actual superheat available is sufficient to vaporize at least 95% of MeOH, which is NOT expected to result in catastrophic tube failure.  This is expected to be worst case scenario.

LOPA Scenario - 586.1, Offload High NH3 Railcar to 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with resulting Vessel Leak.  Assume 100% NH3 at 90 F (vapor pressure = 165 psig, >1.3x MAWP of 100 psig) and 0.6" diameter hole per AA Guidelines (based on 3" bottom flange).  Material released is liquid at 2m.

LOPA Scenario - 586.1, Offload High NH3 Railcar to 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with resulting Vessel Leak.  Assume 100% NH3 at 90 F (vapor pressure = 165 psig, >1.3x MAWP of 100 psig) and 1" diameter hole per AA Guidelines (based on 18" top manway).  Material released is vapor at 5m.

LOPA Scenario - 586.1, Offload High NH3 Railcar to 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Relief Valve Lift (vapor ONLY). Assume liquid feed rate of 150 gpm (44,370 lb/hr) of NH3 at 90 F.  All NH3 will vaporize at 100 psig PSV setting.
MIPA Solution Loading Pump Fails
MIPA Solution Loading Hose Rupture
MIPA Solution Storage Tank Roof Damage

LOPA Scenario - 586.2, Hydrostatic overfill of 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Vessel Failure (several pumps in the system can exceed 2x MAWP).  Because this is a liquid full (hydrostatic) failure, the rate of release will be considered the same as the liquid feed to the vessel.  In this case 150 gpm (67,860 lb/hr) is used.  The release is assumed to be at 2m (bottom of the vessel.  An average 134B composition (based on 4 years of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.

LOPA Scenario - 586.3 & 586.4, Overpressure 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Catastrophic Failure.  Overpressure from blocked in or failed vent valve.   An average 134B composition (based on 4 years of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.

LOPA Scenario - 586.3 & 586.4, Overpressure of 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Relief Valve Lift (vapor ONLY). Assume liquid feed rate of 150 gpm = vapor rate of 20 scfm = 670 lb/hr.  Composition is mostly Nitrogen, based on average 134B composition (4 years of analytical data).

LOPA Scenario - 691.1, 691.2, 692.2, 692.4, Hydrostatic overfill of 134A/C Methyls Crude Storage Tank with Vessel Failure (several pumps in the system can exceed 2x MAWP).  Because this is a liquid full (hydrostatic) failure, the rate of release will be considered the same as the liquid feed to the vessel.  In this case 150 gpm (48,960 lb/hr) is used.  The release is assumed to be at 2m (bottom of the vessel).  An average 134A/C composition (based on 1 year of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.

LOPA Scenario - 691.1 & 691.2, 692.1, 692.3, Hydrostatic overfill of 134A/C Methyls Crude Storage Tank with Relief Valve lifting at 150 gpm (48,960 lb/hr) feed rate.  An average 134A/C composition (based on 1 year of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.

Description: LOPA Scenario - 586.5, Hydrostatic overfill of 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Vessel Failure (several pumps in the system can exceed 2x MAWP).  Because this is a liquid full (hydrostatic) failure, the rate of release will be considered the same as the liquid feed to the vessel.  In this case 55 gpm (25,000 lb/hr) is used.  This rate has been reduced because backflow must go through 1" pump discharge piping.   The release is assumed to be at 2m (bottom of the vessel).  An average 134B composition (based on 4 years of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.

LOPA Scenario - 35.1 - Loss of NH3 Feed, resulting in exotherm on catalyst bed in Converter, resulting in temperatures exceeding MAWT 1,100 F.  Worse case calculations suggest a temperature of approximately 1,350 F is achievable over a small area of the Converter (~10%).  This could cause a reduction in the vessels pressure retaining capability, but not expected to achieve 2x MAWP (catastrophic failure). Although,>1.3x MAWP maybe possible.  Therefore, a manway flange leak (1") on the Converter is analyzed per AA LOPA guidelines.

3. Catastrophic rupture of storage tank 8820 (low pressure storage tank)
4. Leak of 258m³ diluted formic acid and suphuric acid mixture 

Consequence 5.2.2.1
1. Too much nitrogen flows to storage tank 8820
2. Nitrogen overpressurizes the atmospheric storage tank 8820
3. Catastrophic rupture of storage tank 8820
4. Spill of FA and SA mixture 

Consequence 5.6.1.1
1. Faster decomposition of FA94% because it is mixed with SA 
2. Formic acid fumes build up 
3. Pressure rises in storage tank 8820
4. Catastrophic rupture of storage tank 8820
5. Release of FA and SA mixture

Consequence 5.7.2.1
1. Nitrogen is added to tank 8820
2. Overpressurizing tank 8820
3. Catastrophic rupture of storage tank 8820
4. Spill of FA and SA mixture 

Consequence 5.7.2.2

2. Overpressurizing tank 8820

3. Vapours overpressurizes the atmospheric storage tank 8820

5. Spill of FA and SA mixture

Description: Corrosion causes vessel leak/failure and Ethylene release to the area with possible fire or explosion. - COPY - 12/01/2024 15:49:24 -05:00
C5R capacity increase exceeds temperature control capacity leading to liquid condensing in the recycle stream leading to liquid being fed to the compressor.
LOPATargetDiscussion: Capacity increase to 3600 lbs/hr being fed to the ethylene compressor C5R.    Consequence is based on liquid sluggin and compression  blowing out the end plates of the compressor.  Another scenario would be a small amount causing lubrication to washing away leading to bearing or valve failure (smaller leak).   Liquid in the compressor suction has a potential for low temperature embrittlement.

If the dope flow is too high relative to the air flow due to instrument/control loop malfunction, human error, blower malfunction or improper valve setting, etc., the potential exists for the acetone concentration in the air in the spinning machine to rise above the LEL and if ignited, could result in a spinning machine flash fire/explosion. leading to potential severe injury to personnel.   The high flow of dope will likely result in adverse spinning conditions which may ultimately shutdown spinning.

CABINET ONLY RELEASE

Temp in cabinet ranges from 60-80degC. 
average dope flow: 2500 ccs/min (1 machine) = 0.66 gpm
time to notice spill: immediately-10mins
Rec 3610 - 100 scfm (using 379 ft3/lb-mol, 30.79 ave mw)

Description: LOPA Scenario - 586.5, Hydrostatic overfill of 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Relief Valve lifting at 5 gpm (2,500 lb/hr) feed rate.  An average 134B composition (based on 4 years of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.  This scenario models typical flow from Vent Scrubber when #1 unit is down.  Vent Scrubber pump P-67175A/B have sufficient TGH to lift PSV.

TTID 3178
Scen1: Overpressure with gas
Rev A 17.12.2024
LOPATargetDiscussion:
TTID 3178: Overpressure with gas. Release to atm at syngas hall roof. Model based on following documents: 1019699_Oulu_916749-1_712357_0.pdf, 1019699_Oulu_916749-1_712358_0.pdf
Actual capacity 37292 kg/h. Inventory = compressor capacity 13362 kg/h. Overpressure with gas is considered as a credible relief case because the blocked discharge in the outlet path of reciprocating compressor 660P can produce infinite pressure which can overpressure 660P Discharge piping and downstream equipment's. Height of the valve's discharge is at 16 m.
1019647_Oulu_Occupancy Worksheet_20240606_RevB.pdf loc. 13.

Description:
What are the potential consequences if the level control is lost on TK-58C?
Level control failure results in TK-58C overfilling with APO wax, which flows to D-1 and then to TK-66B. This could result in wax compromising the flare header, resulting in LOPC due to overpressure of TK-66B.
Wax overfilling TK-58C-2 represents a closed outlet scenario of the reactors, in which they would relieve to TK-59C, which vents to TK-66B, which relieves to the flare header. Potential LOPC at TK-66B with plugged flare header; assuming relief flow from one reactor through a 1/2" hole on T-66B at 2.13x MAWP.
30.4.1 Manual valves closed in inlet to D-125; Complete loss of cooling. Potential to increase pressure in T-105

Description:
Level control failure on TK-58C-2 (LV-705A-38C closes unexpectedly, due to valve malfunction or issue with the DCS controller). This failure causes TK-58C-2 to overfill with APO wax, which could block off the normal vent path for the propylene and solvent that also flows to this tank from the APO reactors. Overfilling would also block off PSV-TK58C-2, preventing the PSV from being effective. The APO reactors normally operate at ~1,000 psig, which represents over-pressuring TK-58C-2 by 1.8x MAWP.
Will model various failures (1/2" hole, 1" hole, 2" hole, catastrophic failure) at TK-58C-2.

Case 2 (0.81 kg/hr NOx)

we are performing a risk assessment for working on a platform near the flare tip. The distance between the top of the burner and working people is around 7,6 m (see sketch below).

One discussion point was: If there is NOx (NO2) present in the working area and could that injure the people that are working there.
NO2 is formed if Ammonia (NH3), Methylamine (MMA), Dimehtylamine (DMA), Trimethylamine (TMA) get combusted.

E-67051A/B MeOH Preheaters, Overpressure from CLOSED downstream valve on MeOH Feed Line and deadheaded pump pressure.  Pump can potential exceed 1.3x MAWP of Exchangers, resulting in leak on 3" flange.  0.6" hole is used per AA LOPA Guidelines.

T-67025 DEHY Column.  Relief Valve Lifts due to loss of cooling.  Note that per the PSV calculations is the worst case.  72,000 lb/hr 33 w% MMA and 67 w% DMA are used.  Composition is adjusted to give all vapor at release (no liquid).
E-67054 NH3 Economizer.  Instantaneous Tube Failure leads to subsequent Shell Failure/Leak.  Release of NH3 at rate calculated in PSV-91 sizing, 28,551 lb/hr.

LOPA Scenario - 586.5, Hydrostatic overfill of 134B High-Water Crude Storage Tank with Relief Valve lifting at VARIOUS feed rates.  An average 134B composition (based on 4 years of analytical data) is used to model the material in vessel.  This scenario models likely reduced flowrate at higher tank pressures.

Due to addition of water to BG-01 by the process when BG-01 still has peroxide feed supplying the reactor, then water could slow the rate of the reaction in BG-01.  If the response to this is to add enough acid feed to neutralize the water or if the initiating scenario of water addition is stopped, any excess acid could cause the reaction rate to increase.  In addition the reaction would shift to BG-02 and/or AS-50 resulting in vapor release (through the scrubber, vent stack and/or AS-50 relief).

If the response to this is to add enough acid feed to neutralize the water or if the initiating scenario of water addition is stopped, any excess acid could cause the reaction rate to increase. Ex 1 - Catastrophic

Level control failure on an acetic anhydride tank (API 650) results in overfill and overpressure
Tank is filled at 100 gpm
Tank has not been evaluated for top vs bottom weld seam failure
Current evaluation
Assume catastrophic failure of tank and release of full contents
Proposed method
Overflow release
100 gpm is released from the bottom of the tank for 30 min (or a period determined by the team) followed by the tank contents deinventorying at the same rate through the hole

Ex 1 - Rate-based

Level control failure on an acetic anhydride tank (API 650) results in overfill and overpressure
Tank is filled at 100 gpm
Tank has not been evaluated for top vs bottom weld seam failure
Current evaluation
Assume catastrophic failure of tank and release of full contents
Proposed method
Overflow release
100 gpm is released from the bottom of the tank for 30 min (or a period determined by the team) followed by the tank contents deinventorying at the same rate through the hole

Ex 2 - Catastrophic

A distillation column loses condensing causing overpressure.  The column and associated equipment have MAWPs of 100 psig.  The resulting pressure from the loss of cooling case is 170 psig.  The relief system on the column is not adequate for the scenario.
Current evaluation:
Evaluate catastrophic failure of the column with a vessel integrity credit of -1 above 1.3 times the MAWP but below 2.5 times.
Proposed method
For a pressure vessel subjected to pressures greater than 1.3 but less than 2.0 times the MAWP, evaluate gasket leak
Gasket leak would be evaluated as ½” hole at the base of the column

Ex 2 - Gasket Leak

A distillation column loses condensing causing overpressure.  The column and associated equipment have MAWPs of 100 psig.  The resulting pressure from the loss of cooling case is 170 psig.  The relief system on the column is not adequate for the scenario.
Current evaluation:
Evaluate catastrophic failure of the column with a vessel integrity credit of -1 above 1.3 times the MAWP but below 2.5 times.
Proposed method
For a pressure vessel subjected to pressures greater than 1.3 but less than 2.0 times the MAWP, evaluate gasket leak
Gasket leak would be evaluated as ½” hole at the base of the column

Ex 3 - Equipment Rupture

A similar column (to Ex 2) could lose cooling.  This column has a 75 psig pressure rating and could be subjected to the same 170 psig.  
Current evaluation:
Evaluate catastrophic failure of the column with a vessel integrity credit of -1 above 1.3 times the MAWP but below 2.5 times.
Proposed method
For a pressure vessel subjected to pressures greater than 2.0 times the MAWP, evaluate equipment rupture
Equipment rupture for a high-pressure failure is instantaneous failure and release of the contents

10TH FLOOR
65 deg C (loss of cooling)

98% meoh 2% water

modeling 15 min worth of flow

per Alexander Niccum email - 9/25/2024

-	For the three Tetrashield grades we will produce on X-Line, the highest amount of methanol that is being refined is 62 lbs./min.
-	The MPPE-900 scrubber can only condense 2.7 lbs./min of methanol based on the minimum required flow of 2 gpm, so the scrubber will only have a small impact.
-	That being said, the scenario references that the overhead condenser (XL-21) would still be operational. XL-21 can condense 40 lbs./min based on process trend data over the last 5 years.  

Based on these findings, I would recommend using 20 lbs./min to model the loss of reflux scenario.

-	The MPPE-900 scrubber can only condense 2.7 lbs./min of methanol based on the minimum required flow of 2 gpm, so the scrubber will only have a small impact.
-	That being said, the scenario references that the overhead condenser (XL-21) would still be operational. XL-21 can condense 40 lbs./min based on process trend data over the last 5 years.

Cause: BPCS Failure - FV-0131-009 fails in close position.  (Loss of steam to E-131, BPCS loop includes Level Controller for Vaporizer E-131 LC-0131-004, Steam Flow Controller FC-0131-009); OR cause: Operator Error - Overfills liquid Methanol in Methanol Vaporizer E-131.

Consequence: High level of liquid Methanol in Methanol Vaporizer E-131. Potential for liquid overflow into the superheater. Could lead to excess heating. Vaporize more methanol than intended in the superheater. Overpressure of Methanol Superheater. Potential for BLEVE. Personnel Exposure.
LOPATargetDiscussion: Excessive heating of methanol in superheater could lead to overpressure more than 4xMAWP. For catastrophic failure, using 4xMAWP at the superheater 140.E-132 (As per the Target Table Protocol Update - Maximum Pressure for Vessel Failure Model). Methanol flow to preheater is 144581 lb/hr. Converting lb to kg i.e., 65580 kg in 60 minutes.

Cause: Operator Error - Unloading Product D Tank Truck with Product D storage tank already high level.
Consequence: Overfill Product D Storage Tank TK-15. Potential for fire. Personnel exposure.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
Product D Unloading Pump 143.P-25 capacity is 65 GPM. This could be ~12755 kg in 60 minutes, that is equivalent to 28110 lb/hr. The Product D tank truck is expected to have a capacity of 8000 gal, i.e., 26,000 kg. Product D tank truck unloading into the Product D storage tank would take more than 60 minutes. Checked with Mike James, he recommended considering target table calculation for 60 minutes at the unloading flowrate. 

Trade secret note (03/13/2025): Target table needs information about the specific chemical. To meet the POP trade secret requirement, the dispersion modeling for Product D will be run on offline machine by Mike James and applied to this target table. Mike James directed to use Water as the chemical in the chemical list below to let the dummy calculation run in the target table.

Target table for Product D was performed by Mike James on his local machine, the results are as follows (03/13/2025): "the model for the Product D target table returned Serious with a POE -2 as the largest hazard.  Both Flash Fire and Inhalation had this same target.  It was consistent from 15 minutes to 60 minutes giving the same result."
Interpretation:
From 15 mins to 60 mins:

Flash fire: Serious
POE: -2

Inhalation: Serious
POE: -2

Isobutylene Storage Tank - Block and Bleed Configuration Valve Failure
LOPATargetDiscussion: If both valves on the liquid lines are closed during normal activities a section of piping could have blocked in liquid, resulting in potential for high pressure due to thermal expansion.  The high pressure could lead to line failure and a release of isobutylene to area and fire hazards and related injury.  Based on pressure ratings that were checked during the PHA, the valve is expected to fail before the piping.  Failure of the valve closest to the tank could result in loss of the tank contents. This was model as a 2" leak out the top of the tank due to failure of the valve body on the valve closest to the tank

Cause: PET Feedstock BPCS loop failure (Sending too much PET to the Dissolver)
Consequence: T-101 overfills into D-710. Hot PET melt in liq. MeOH could overpressure D-710.
LOPATargetDiscussion:
High flow of PET to the Dissolver leads to high level in Dissolver T-101. Dissolver could overfill into the Dissolver Process Vessel 2 D-710. Hot PET melt could flash liquid methanol in D-710.

HMB: Assuming the high flow PET also brings in equivalent composition of other components in the Dissolver system. This assumption could mean the drain composition from Dissolver could overflow into DPV2. 
Major components in Dissolver: DIMETHYL TEREPHTHALATE (17%), 1,4-BENZENEDICARBOXYLIC ACID, 2-HYDROXYETHYL METHYL ESTER	(6%), BIS-(2-HYDROXYETHYL) TEREPHTHALATE (70%).

4500 lb to be equivalent to ~2041 kg.

Level control failure on TK-58C-2 (LV-705A-38C closes unexpectedly, due to valve malfunction or issue with the DCS controller). This failure causes TK-58C-2 to overfill into D-1 with APO wax. Wax would then flow to TK-66B, where it could accumulate and get into the flare header, blocking it off. The APO wax reactors normally vent through TK-59C and into TK-66B (emergency relief also flows through this path). With TK-66B full of wax, PSV-37C at TK-59C would open to relieve pressure, but the discharge would be blocked with wax from overfilling TK-66B. This could cause a failure at TK-59C.
Will model various failures (1/2" hole, 1" hole, 2" hole, catastrophic failure) at TK-59C.

36PSV-T563:
T-563 is the reflux tank for D-513 which takes ethyl acetate overhead.  T-563 has a dip pipe and cannot be relieved through PSV-750 on D-513. Project is specifying a new relief valve for T-563 with new inlet and outlet piping, since the D-513 column relief device has been deemed unable to provide overpressure protection for T-563.  The controlling scenario is external fire (required capacity = 6782 lb/hr ethyl acetate; actual capacity = 7037 lb/hr ethyl acetate).  Top of proposed nozzle is 13'10" above grade.  Assumed discharge was at an elevation of 15'10" above grade (4.826 meters).  Normal operating level is 42"; modeled assuming that the volume was 50% of the tangential height plus the bottom head.
LOPATargetDiscussion: Relief device EOS indicates two credible relief cases for PSV-T563:  tube rupture of E-578 (114 gpm water) and external fire (6782.158 lb/hr ethyl acetate).  Target table indicated -2 for probability of exposure for both inhalation and flash fire hazards with vertical discharge orientation, just above the top of the tank (elevation of ~15'10" above grade).  Dispersion model indicates the plume will be a vertical rise with limited lateral impact.  Recommend routing the discharge pipe up with elevation at least 15'10" above grade. Provide a weep hole to allow water drainage.

36PSV-T570:  
T-570 is the reflux tank for D-514 which takes ethyl acetate overhead.  T-570 has a dip pipe and cannot be relieved through RV-761 on D-514. Project is specifying a new relief valve for T-570 with new inlet and outlet piping, since the D-514 column relief device has been deemed unable to provide overpressure protection for T-570.  The controlling scenario is external fire (required capacity = 3310 lb/hr ethyl acetate; actual capacity = 4999 lb/hr ethyl acetate).  Top of proposed nozzle is 9.13' above grade.  Assume discharge height is 14' above grade (4.2672 m).  Normal operating level is 35%; modeled assuming that the volume was 50% of the tangential height plus the bottom head.
LOPATargetDiscussion: Relief device EOS indicates one credible relief case for PSV-T570:  external fire (3310 lb/hr ethyl acetate; actual device capacity = 4999 lb/hr ethyl acetate).  Target table indicated -2 for probability of exposure for both inhalation and flash fire hazards with vertical discharge orientation, just above the top of the tank (elevation of 14' above grade).  Dispersion model indicates the plume will be a vertical rise with limited lateral impact.  Recommend routing the discharge pipe up with elevation at least 14' above grade. Provide a weep hole to allow water drainage.

Description:
36RV-697 Automatic Control Failure:  
R-901 is a trickle bed hydrogenation reactor which converts impurities [i-butyraldehyde, isobutyl alcohol and acetals] in the ethyl acetate feed stream to alcohols and saturated ethers. The reactor normally operates at 325 psig and 300°F.  The controlling scenario is automatic control failure of N2 regulator on 16pk of N2 (required capacity = 8977 lb/hr N2; actual capacity = 101437 lb/hr N2).  Top of PSV discharge is 30' above grade (9.144).  Assumed vessel filled to top seam (1.98 m3).

36RV-697 External Fire:  
R-901 is a trickle bed hydrogenation reactor which converts impurities [i-butyraldehyde, isobutyl alcohol and acetals] in the ethyl acetate feed stream to alcohols and saturated ethers. The reactor normally operates at 325 psig and 300°F.  External fire is a credible scenario but not the controlling case (required capacity = 13489 lb/hr Ethyl Acetate; actual capacity = 233625.6 lb/hr N2).  Top of PSV discharge is 30' above grade (9.144).  Assumed vessel filled to top seam (1.98 m3).
